repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
relates to #1008 

As a first step, to disable it first to see what has to be fixed before it's removed completely

Some infos:

- powershell uses `UTF-8` as default since v7.1 (without BOM see [here](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_character_encoding?view=powershell-7.5#character-encoding-in-powershell))
- it communicates internally with `UTF-16LE`
- it cannot read directly from `stdin` and we have to use `$input` for that (see [here](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/9497))
- there is also difference if we use `commands` or `cmdlets` in regards of `stdin` handling, how it's currently written here seems to work with both.
- encoding could also differ depending on the `cmdlet` which is used last, not all of them have `-Encoding` property

comment_data.body: It's nuts that 'shelltemp' was triggering this elaborate wrapper. Eliminating 'shelltemp' may require some bug fixes or documented constraints, but will likely result in more reliable and predictable behavior.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -567,14 +567,14 @@ describe('shell :!', function()
       4
       2]])
     if is_os('win') then
-      feed(':4verbose %!sort /R<cr>')
+      feed(':4verbose %!& sort /R<cr>')
       screen:expect {
-        any = [[Executing command: .?& { Get%-Content .* | & sort /R } 2>&1 | %%{ "$_" } | Out%-File .*; exit $LastExitCode"]],
+        any = [[Executing command: "& sort /R".*]],

comment_data.body: just `return`. `pending` is for things that require attention in the future. Don't want the "skipped tests" list to grow permanently for things that cannot be fixed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -596,22 +596,21 @@ describe('shell :!', function()
       4
       2]])
     feed(':4verbose %w !sort<cr>')
-    if is_os('win') then
-      screen:expect {
-        any = [[Executing command: .?sort %< .*]],
-      }
+    screen:expect {
+      any = [[Executing command: "sort".*]],
+    }
+    feed('<CR>')
+
+    if not n.has_powershell() then
+      pending('powershell not found, skip powershell part', function() end)

comment_data.body: This is something that we'll need to resolve. Which commands below are triggered  `FileWritePre`/`FileWritePost`, and should they do so for 'noshelltemp' too?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2835,6 +2835,9 @@ func Test_ReadWrite_Autocmds()
   " being modified outside of Vim (noticed on Solaris).
   au FileChangedShell * echo 'caught FileChangedShell'
 
+  " FileWritePre, FileWritePost are only triggered with shelltemp here
+  let shelltemp = &shelltemp

comment_data.body:
I think the tests do too much here, they should only check autocommand which I think could be easier tested then using an external command (gzip) and `!`. It only triggered the file events as a side effect of the bang implementation here (with `shelltemp` on).

So my suggestion would be to use regular `write` and `read` commands to test the autocommand functionality and we may create separate tests for the encoding and decoding issues of bang, which is a separate concern which should not break these tests here. 

What do you think?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2835,6 +2835,9 @@ func Test_ReadWrite_Autocmds()
   " being modified outside of Vim (noticed on Solaris).
   au FileChangedShell * echo 'caught FileChangedShell'
 
+  " FileWritePre, FileWritePost are only triggered with shelltemp here
+  let shelltemp = &shelltemp

comment_data.body: I added an example on how it could look like in the lua counterpart of the similar tests. I would make the other changes if we agree on how we want to proceed here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2835,6 +2835,9 @@ func Test_ReadWrite_Autocmds()
   " being modified outside of Vim (noticed on Solaris).
   au FileChangedShell * echo 'caught FileChangedShell'
 
+  " FileWritePre, FileWritePost are only triggered with shelltemp here
+  let shelltemp = &shelltemp

comment_data.body: Yes, removing those extras should simplify things and after removing `shelltemp` make the process more strait forward and less error prone (I hope :) ), but will introduce a breaking change in some cases I guess.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -567,14 +567,14 @@ describe('shell :!', function()
       4
       2]])
     if is_os('win') then
-      feed(':4verbose %!sort /R<cr>')
+      feed(':4verbose %!& sort /R<cr>')
       screen:expect {
-        any = [[Executing command: .?& { Get%-Content .* | & sort /R } 2>&1 | %%{ "$_" } | Out%-File .*; exit $LastExitCode"]],
+        any = [[Executing command: "& sort /R".*]],

comment_data.body:
> my suggestion would be to use regular `write` and `read` commands to test the autocommand functionality and we may create separate tests for the encoding and decoding issues of bang,

That could be fine for this test, but there is still the larger question of whether FileWritePre/FileWritePost should work even without 'shelltemp'. Are they useful?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2835,6 +2835,9 @@ func Test_ReadWrite_Autocmds()
   " being modified outside of Vim (noticed on Solaris).
   au FileChangedShell * echo 'caught FileChangedShell'
 
+  " FileWritePre, FileWritePost are only triggered with shelltemp here
+  let shelltemp = &shelltemp

comment_data.body: You mean if we should trigger those events when we pipe into or from the `!` command? I personally would not, because for me this is not an actual writing/reading a file and I would not expect it to trigger them.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2835,6 +2835,9 @@ func Test_ReadWrite_Autocmds()
   " being modified outside of Vim (noticed on Solaris).
   au FileChangedShell * echo 'caught FileChangedShell'
 
+  " FileWritePre, FileWritePost are only triggered with shelltemp here
+  let shelltemp = &shelltemp

comment_data.body:
maybe someone with an windows machine can answer here.

I could not find any native tee.exe command available for windows, only an powershell alias but this is disabled some lines above, so I am wondering how this worked in tests on windows machines.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -668,10 +668,11 @@ function M.set_shell_powershell(fake)
     set shellquote= shellxquote=
     let &shellcmdflag = '-NoLogo -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Command '
     let &shellcmdflag .= '[Console]::InputEncoding=[Console]::OutputEncoding=[System.Text.UTF8Encoding]::new();'
-    let &shellcmdflag .= '$PSDefaultParameterValues[''Out-File:Encoding'']=''utf8'';'
+    let &shellcmdflag .= '$PSDefaultParameterValues[''*:Encoding'']=''utf8'';'
+    let &shellcmdflag .= '$ErrorActionPreference=''SilentlyContinue'';'
     let &shellcmdflag .= ']] .. cmd .. [['
     let &shellredir = '2>&1 | %%{ "$_" } | Out-File %s; exit $LastExitCode'
-    let &shellpipe  = '2>&1 | %%{ "$_" } | tee %s; exit $LastExitCode'

comment_data.body: I think this check can be removed, because in the powershell v7.4 (LTS) the executable was renamed to `pwsh.exe` [see in the docs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell?view=powershell-7.4#powershell-executable-changes)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -642,7 +642,7 @@ function M.source(code)
 end
 
 function M.has_powershell()
-  return M.eval('executable("' .. (is_os('win') and 'powershell' or 'pwsh') .. '")') == 1

comment_data.body: Question would be also, if we want to support `Windows PowerShell 5.1` which is far behind the cross platform powershell version and I guess our CI pipeline would not catch any errors here (but not entirely sure), because in the GitHub windows runners the v7.4 LTS is installed
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -642,7 +642,7 @@ function M.source(code)
 end
 
 function M.has_powershell()
-  return M.eval('executable("' .. (is_os('win') and 'powershell' or 'pwsh') .. '")') == 1

comment_data.body: I think you need to check `off + 1 < remaining` here.
Oh, actually it's not needed, as the string is NUL-terminated.
Nice catch, thx
The GitHub runner has it?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -668,10 +668,11 @@ function M.set_shell_powershell(fake)
     set shellquote= shellxquote=
     let &shellcmdflag = '-NoLogo -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Command '
     let &shellcmdflag .= '[Console]::InputEncoding=[Console]::OutputEncoding=[System.Text.UTF8Encoding]::new();'
-    let &shellcmdflag .= '$PSDefaultParameterValues[''Out-File:Encoding'']=''utf8'';'
+    let &shellcmdflag .= '$PSDefaultParameterValues[''*:Encoding'']=''utf8'';'
+    let &shellcmdflag .= '$ErrorActionPreference=''SilentlyContinue'';'
     let &shellcmdflag .= ']] .. cmd .. [['
     let &shellredir = '2>&1 | %%{ "$_" } | Out-File %s; exit $LastExitCode'
-    let &shellpipe  = '2>&1 | %%{ "$_" } | tee %s; exit $LastExitCode'

comment_data.body: I could not find any additional tools that are part of the agent, which would contain it. So I am currently clueless.

comment_data.body:
nit
```suggestion
      ml_append(curwin->w_cursor.lnum++, output, (int)off + 1, false);
```

I think because the only test for this just checks the logs, not the result: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/f068386c9f709c586f44169f4566b4e31ce973de/test/functional/vimscript/system_spec.lua#L571-L573

And the make_spec was not using powershell: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/f068386c9f709c586f44169f4566b4e31ce973de/test/functional/ex_cmds/make_spec.lua#L37
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -668,10 +668,11 @@ function M.set_shell_powershell(fake)
     set shellquote= shellxquote=
     let &shellcmdflag = '-NoLogo -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Command '
     let &shellcmdflag .= '[Console]::InputEncoding=[Console]::OutputEncoding=[System.Text.UTF8Encoding]::new();'
-    let &shellcmdflag .= '$PSDefaultParameterValues[''Out-File:Encoding'']=''utf8'';'
+    let &shellcmdflag .= '$PSDefaultParameterValues[''*:Encoding'']=''utf8'';'
+    let &shellcmdflag .= '$ErrorActionPreference=''SilentlyContinue'';'
     let &shellcmdflag .= ']] .. cmd .. [['
     let &shellredir = '2>&1 | %%{ "$_" } | Out-File %s; exit $LastExitCode'
-    let &shellpipe  = '2>&1 | %%{ "$_" } | tee %s; exit $LastExitCode'

comment_data.body:
Let's just `return`. It's noisy to see lots of "skipped" tests for CI envs that don't have powershell. Same for the other cases below.

We generally want to mark "skipped" for tests that need attention (and are actionable).

```suggestion
      return
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -558,9 +558,13 @@ end)
 describe('shell :!', function()
   before_each(clear)
 
-  it(':{range}! with powershell filter/redirect #16271 #19250', function()
+  it(':{range}! with powershell using "commands" filter/redirect #16271 #19250', function()
+    if not n.has_powershell() then
+      pending('powershell not found', function() end)
+      return

comment_data.body: you already said that before, I forgot to it it here, I will try to memorize that rule for the next time :)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
 'shelltemp' defaults to "false".
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -81,6 +81,7 @@ OPTIONS
  'chistory' and 'lhistory' set size of the |quickfix-stack|.
  'diffopt' `inline:` configures diff highlighting for changes within a line.
  'pummaxwidth' sets maximum width for the completion popup menu.
+ 'shelltemp' default to "false".

comment_data.body: Thinking about this again, since `set shelltemp` is now added to `testdir/setup.vim`, this change is no longer needed. And if the next step is to remove the `'shelltemp'` option, a different and more careful change will be needed for this test anyway.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2055,6 +2055,7 @@ endfunc
 " Test error: "E135: *Filter* Autocommands must not change current buffer"
 func Test_cmd_bang_E135()
   new
+  set shelltemp

comment_data.body: ditto
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2835,6 +2835,9 @@ func Test_ReadWrite_Autocmds()
   " being modified outside of Vim (noticed on Solaris).
   au FileChangedShell * echo 'caught FileChangedShell'
 
+  " FileWritePre, FileWritePost are only triggered with shelltemp here
+  let shelltemp = &shelltemp
+  set shelltemp			" need temp files here

comment_data.body: ditto
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2879,6 +2882,8 @@ func Test_ReadWrite_Autocmds()
     au!
   augroup END
 
+  let &shelltemp = shelltemp
+

comment_data.body: Good point, will undo those changes.

@@ -2055,6 +2055,7 @@ endfunc
 " Test error: "E135: *Filter* Autocommands must not change current buffer"
 func Test_cmd_bang_E135()

comment_regular_data.body: Avoid modifying individual oldtests. Add `set shelltemp` to `test/old/testdir/setup.vim` instead.

> Avoid modifying individual oldtests. Add `set shelltemp` to `test/old/testdir/setup.vim` instead.

You mean I should revert already made changes in there or just don't add further changes? I am fine with both, just wanna clarify what you mean.
Actually I'm not sure either. Since there are only a few oldtest failures maybe it's better to fix the functionaltest failures first.
@justinmk should I squash the commits or do we squash the whole PR when we merge?
This test fails the first time, is it flaky? I couldn't see anything that I changed could caused it, also not sure how to re trigger the CI to see if it will pass.

title: feat(defaults): shelltemp=false
